{{Infobox company | name = Institute for Systems Biology | type = non-profit | founded = 2000 | founder = [[Leroy Hood]], [[Alan Aderem]], [[Ruedi Aebersold]] | location_city = Seattle, Washington | location_country = United States | location = | key_people = James R. Heath, PhD, President
Leroy Hood, MD, PhD, Chief Strategy Officer and Co-founder
Nitin Baliga, PhD, Senior Vice President and Director
Nathan Price, PhD, Associate Director | area_served = Systems Biology | industry = Biology | products = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | num_employees = 230 | parent = | subsid = | owner = | homepage = http://www.systemsbiology.org | footnotes = }} [[File:ISB Headquarters in South Lake Union.jpg|thumb|This is the front entrance of Institute for Systems Biology in Seattle's South Lake Union neighborhood at 401 Terry Ave. N.]] '''Institute for Systems Biology''' (ISB) is a [[non-profit]] research institution located in [[Seattle, Washington]], United States.{{cite web|title=Institute for Systems Biology - Home|url=http://www.systemsbiology.org/|publisher=Institute for Systems Biology|accessdate=17 March 2012}} The ISB concentrates on [[systems biology]], the study of relationships and interactions between various parts of biological systems, and advocates an [[interdisciplinary]] approach to biological research.{{Cite journal | last1 = Hood | first1 = L. | last2 = Rowen | first2 = L. | last3 = Galas | first3 = D. J. | last4 = Aitchison | first4 = J. D. | title = Systems biology at the Institute for Systems Biology | doi = 10.1093/bfgp/eln027 | journal = Briefings in Functional Genomics and Proteomics | volume = 7 | issue = 4 | pages = 239–248 | year = 2008 | pmid = 18579616 | pmc = }} ==Goals== Systems biology attempts to study biological systems in a holistic manner by integrating data at all levels of the biological information hierarchy, from global down to the individual organism, and below down to the molecular level. The vision of ISB has been to integrate these concepts using a cross-disciplinary approach combining the efforts of biologists, chemists, computer scientists, engineers, mathematicians, physicists, and physicians. On its website, ISB has defined four areas of focus:{{cite web|title=Institute for Systems Biology - Research|url=http://www.systemsbiology.org/research|publisher=Institute for Systems Biology|accessdate=17 March 2012}} * P4 Medicine - This acronym refers to predictive, preventive, personalized and participatory medicine, which focuses on wellness rather than the mere treatment of disease. * Global Health - Use of the systems approach towards the study of infectious diseases, vaccine development, emergence of chronic diseases, and maternal and child health. * Sustainable Environment - Applying systems biology for a better understanding of the role of microbes in the environment and their relation to human health. * Education & Outreach - Knowledge transfer to society through a variety of educational programs and partnerships, including the spinout of new companies. ==Early history== [[File:Leroy Hood podium PITT2008.JPG|thumb|right|Leroy Hood, 2008]] [[File:Aderem 00044.jpg|thumb|right | Alan Aderem, 2012]] [[File:Ruedi Aebersold 2012.JPG|thumb|right| Ruedi Aebersold, 2012]] [[Leroy Hood]] co-founded the Institute with [[Alan Aderem]] and [[Ruedi Aebersold]] in 2000. However, the story of how ISB got started actually begins in 1990.{{cite news|last=Dietrich|first=Bill|title=Future Perfect -- Thanks To Bill Gates' $12-Million Endowment, Scientist Leroy Hood Continues His Search For A New Genetic Destiny|url=http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?date=19920209&slug=1474735|accessdate=17 March 2012|newspaper=The Seattle Times|date=9 February 1992}} Lee Hood was the director of a large molecular biotechnology lab at the [[California Institute of Technology]] in Pasadena, and was a key advisor in the [[Human Genome Project]], having overseen development of machines that were instrumental to its later success. The [[University of Washington]] (UW), like many other universities, was eager to recruit Hood, but had neither the space nor the money to accommodate Hood's large laboratory. Lee Huntsman, director of UW's Center for Bioengineering, was attending a UW football game, sharing a luxury box with [[Bill Gates]], the former CEO and current chairman of [[Microsoft]]. Huntsman took the opportunity to tell Gates about Hood. Bill Gates already had a considerable interest in biotechnology, both as a philanthropist and as an investor, and after meeting Hood, donated $12 million to UW to enable him to head a new department of molecular biotechnology, where Hood continues to hold a faculty position as the Gates Professor of Molecular Biotechnology.{{cite web|title=Department of Molecular Biotechnology|url=http://nick-lab.gs.washington.edu/mbt-web/|publisher=University of Washington|accessdate=17 March 2012}} ISB represents a spin-off of Hood's labs at UW.{{cite web|title=Revolutionary New Science|url=http://www.isepp.org/Pages/01-02%20Pages/Hood.html|publisher=Institute for Science, Engineering and Public Policy|accessdate=17 March 2012}} ==Achievements== ISB is in the top ranks of scientific institutions worldwide. In 2012, the SCImago Research Group, based in Spain, ranked ISB 4th worldwide on its Excellence Rate scale.{{cite web|title=SCImago Research Group|url=http://www.scimago.es/index.php|publisher=SCImago Research Group|accessdate=21 March 2012}} ISB currently hosts 10 research groups with expertise ranging across [[genetics]], [[microbial genetics]], complex molecular machines, macromolecular complexes, [[gene regulatory networks]], [[immunology]], molecular and cell biology, cancer biology, [[genomics]], [[proteomics]], protein chemistry, [[computational biology]] and [[biotechnology]]. The ISB web site lists 985 peer-reviewed publications for the years 2000 through early 2012.{{cite web|title=Institute for Systems Biology - Publications|url=http://www.systemsbiology.org/publications|publisher=Institute for Systems Biology|accessdate=17 March 2012}} In late 2005, the ISB began to emphasize the application of systems biology to P4 medicine (predictive, preventive, personalized, participatory), ''i.e.'' the development of techniques for predicting and preventing disease, possibly before patients even know they are sick. The ''P4 Medicine institute'' was co-founded in 2010 by ISB and [[Ohio State University]].{{cite web|title=P4 Medicine Institute|url=http://p4mi.org/|accessdate=17 March 2012}} The Education and Outreach efforts of ISB include creating the Logan Center for Education whose mission is to enable educators to produce [[Science, technology, engineering, and mathematics|STEM]] literate students.{{cite web |title=Logan Center for Education |url=http://logancenter.systemsbiology.net |publisher=Institute for Systems Biology |accessdate=8 December 2015}} ISB offers paid research internships for high school and undergraduate students, and offers advanced systems science courses throughout the year. ISB has partnered in several high-profile research projects, the most significant one thus far being with the [[Grand Duchy of Luxembourg]] to create the ''Center for Systems Biology Luxembourg''{{cite news|last=Tartakoff|first=Joseph|title=Seattle, Luxembourg research projects set|url=http://www.seattlepi.com/business/article/Seattle-Luxembourg-research-projects-set-1275714.php|accessdate=17 March 2012|newspaper=Seattlepi.com (Seattle Post-Intelligencer)|date=5 June 2008}} and the ''Seattle Proteome Center''.{{cite web|title=Seattle Proteome Center |url=http://www.proteomecenter.org/ |publisher=Seattle Proteome Center|accessdate=17 March 2012}} ISB faculty members have launched five companies: Cytopeia (acquired by BD in 2008), Integrated Diagnostics,{{cite web|title=Integrated Diagnostics|url=http://www.integrated-diagnostics.com/|accessdate=17 March 2012}} Macrogenics,{{cite web |title=Macrogenics |accessdate=17 March 2012|url=http://www.macrogenics.com/}} [[NanoString Technologies]],{{cite web |title=NanoString |url=http://www.nanostring.com/ |accessdate=17 March 2012}} and Accelerator Corporation.{{cite web|title=Accelerator Corporation |url=http://www.acceleratorcorp.com/ |accessdate=17 March 2012}} Accelerator Corporation, in particular, is an investment company that provides venture capital funding and management for biotech startup companies. Its portfolio companies and graduates have focused on improved biotherapeutics, vaccines, biomarkers and other such products. ==See also== * [[List of systems sciences organizations]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== *[http://www.systemsbiology.org/ ISB website] *[http://www.proteomecenter.org/ Seattle Proteome Center] [[Category:Bioinformatics organizations]] [[Category:Systems biology]] [[Category:Systems science institutes]] [[Category:Research institutes in Seattle]] [[Category:Research institutes established in 2000]] [[Category:2000 establishments in Washington (state)]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.6.1)
revision.text:
{{Infobox Organization |name = Intersex Trust Aotearoa New Zealand (aka Intersex Awareness New Zealand) |image = |image_border = |size = |caption = |abbreviation = ITANZ |motto = |formation = 1996 |type = [[NGO]] |status = |purpose = [[Intersex]] human rights |headquarters = |location = |region_served = [[New Zealand]] |membership = |language = |leader_title = Executive Director |leader_name = [[Mani Mitchell]] |main_organ = |affiliations = |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = |website = [http://www.ianz.org.nz/ ianz.org.nz] |remarks = }} Founded by [[Mani Mitchell]] in 1996, '''Intersex Trust Aotearoa New Zealand''', also known as '''Intersex Awareness New Zealand''' is a national advocacy and peer support organisation for intersex people in New Zealand.<ref name="mckenzie">[http://www.jrmckenzie.org.nz/stories/intersex-trust-aotearoa-new-zealand Intersex Trust of Aotearoa New Zealand], J R McKenzie Trust.</ref>
== Mission ==
ITANZ is a charitable trust that provides education, information and training on intersex issues for organisations and individual professionals.<ref name="start">[http://www.ianz.org.nz/ Intersex Awareness New Zealand], Intersex Trust Aotearoa New Zealand, December 2013.</ref><ref>[http://www.teara.govt.nz/en/photograph/28892/intersex-awareness-stall Gender diversity - Intersex people - Intersex awareness stall], Johanna Schmidt, Te Ara - the Encyclopedia of New Zealand, updated 15 November 2012.</ref> Executive Director [[Mani Mitchell]] is known as New Zealand's first "out" intersex person.<ref name="herald2012">{{cite web|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/lifestyle/news/article.cfm?c_id=6&objectid=10800941|publisher=[[The New Zealand Herald]]|title=Being intersex: I went from being my parents' son to a daughter|accessdate=5 September 2012}}</ref>
== Activities ==
The Trust works with the [[Human Rights Commission (New Zealand)|Human Rights Commission]], Rainbow Youth in Auckland, Whanganui Women's Health Collective, and Working it Out in Tasmania.<ref name="hrc2010">{{Cite web| last = Human Rights Commission| title = Intersex sections from the Transgender Inquiry’s final report| date = January 25, 2010| url = https://www.hrc.co.nz/your-rights/social-equality/our-work/inquiry-discrimination-experienced-transgender-people/}}</ref><ref name="hrc2011" />
=== Physical integrity and bodily autonomy ===
Trust members have participated in, and jointly held, roundtable events with the [[Human Rights Commission (New Zealand)|Human Rights Commission]], including on the human rights implications of [[intersex medical interventions]], shame and secrecy.<ref name="hrc2011">{{Cite web| last = Human Rights Commission| title = February 2010 Auckland Intersex Roundtable| date = July 2010| url = https://www.hrc.co.nz/files/5414/3501/0684/24-Sep-2010_11-11-56_February2010Intersex_Roundtable_Minutes_.doc}}</ref><ref name="hrc2016" /> Following a joint round table event with the Human Rights Commission, the Commission proposed to the UN Committee on the Rights of the Child that the New Zealand government enact legal and regulatory safeguards to protect the rights of intersex children, and ensure that children's rights to bodily integrity, autonomy and self-determination are respected.<ref name="hrc2016crc">{{cite web | title = Supplementary submission of the New Zealand Human Rights Commission to the Committee on the Rights of the Child’s 73rd Session | last = Human Rights Commission | author-link = Human Rights Commission (New Zealand) | date = August 15, 2016 | url = http://tbinternet.ohchr.org/_layouts/treatybodyexternal/Download.aspx?symbolno=INT%2fCRC%2fIFN%2fNZL%2f24880&Lang=en }}</ref> In October 2016, the UN Committee on the Rights of the Child issued observations on practices in New Zealand, including recommendations to ensure "that no one is subjected to unnecessary medical or surgical treatment during infancy or childhood, guaranteeing the rights of children to bodily integrity, autonomy and self-determination".<ref name="hrc2016">{{Cite| last = Human Rights Commission| authorlink = Human Rights Commission (New Zealand) | title = Intersex Roundtable Report 2016 The practice of genital normalisation on intersex children in Aotearoa New Zealand| date = 2016| url = https://www.hrc.co.nz/files/5914/8124/9497/HRC_Intersex_Roundtable.pdf}}</ref> The recommendations of the Committee on the Rights of the Child have been illustrated by ITANZ and Intersex Youth Aotearoa.<ref name="iad2016">{{cite web | url = http://intersexday.org/en/aotearoa-crc/ | title = Intersex Youth Aotearoa illustrate UN recommendations | last = Intersex Day | author-link = Intersex Awareness Day | date = October 26, 2016}}</ref>
In March 2017, representatives of Intersex Trust Aotearoa New Zealand participated in an Australian and Aotearoa/New Zealand consensus "Darlington Statement" by intersex community organizations and others.<ref name="darlington2017" /> The statement calls for legal reform, including the criminalization of deferrable [[intersex medical interventions]] on children, an end to legal classification of sex, and improved access to peer support.<ref name="darlington2017">{{Cite| last1 = Androgen Insensitivity Support Syndrome Support Group Australia| author1-link = Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome Support Group Australia | last2 = Intersex Trust Aotearoa New Zealand| author2-link = Intersex Trust Aotearoa New Zealand| last3 = Organisation Intersex International Australia| author3-link = Organisation Intersex International Australia | last4 = Black| first4 = Eve| last5 = Bond| first5 = Kylie| last6 = Briffa| first6 = Tony| author6-link = Tony Briffa | last7 = Carpenter| first7 = Morgan| author7-link = Morgan Carpenter | last8 = Cody| first8 = Candice| last9 = David| first9 = Alex| last10 = Driver| first10 = Betsy| last11 = Hannaford| first11 = Carolyn| last12 = Harlow| first12 = Eileen| last13 = Hart| first13 = Bonnie| author13-link = Bonnie Hart | last14 = Hart| first14 = Phoebe| author14-link = Phoebe Hart | last15 = Leckey| first15 = Delia| last16 = Lum| first16 = Steph| last17 = Mitchell| first17 = Mani Bruce| author17-link = Mani Mitchell | last18 = Nyhuis| first18 = Elise| last19 = O'Callaghan| first19 = Bronwyn| last20 = Perrin| first20 = Sandra| last21 = Smith| first21 = Cody| last22 = Williams| first22 = Trace| last23 = Yang| first23 = Imogen| last24 = Yovanovic| first24 = Georgie| title = Darlington Statement| date = March 2017 | url = https://oii.org.au/darlington-statement/| archive-url = https://eprints.qut.edu.au/104412/ | archive-date = 2017-03-21 | accessdate = March 21, 2017}}</ref><ref name="copland2017ds">{{Cite web| last = Copland| first = Simon| title = Intersex people have called for action. It’s time to listen.| work = [[Special Broadcasting Service]]| accessdate = 2017-03-21| date = March 20, 2017| url = http://www.sbs.com.au/topics/sexuality/agenda/article/2017/03/20/intersex-people-have-called-action-its-time-listen}}</ref><ref name="jones2017ds">{{Cite web| last = Jones| first = Jess| title = Intersex activists in Australia and New Zealand publish statement of priorities| work = [[Star Observer]]| accessdate = 2017-03-21| date = March 10, 2017| url = http://www.starobserver.com.au/news/national-news/intersex-activists-publish-statement-priorities/156425}}</ref><ref name="power2017ds">{{Cite web| last = Power| first = Shannon| title = Intersex advocates pull no punches in historic statement| work = [[Gay Star News]]| accessdate = 2017-03-21| date = March 13, 2017| url = http://www.gaystarnews.com/article/intersex-advocates-darlington-statement/}}</ref><ref name="sainty2017ds">{{Cite web| last = Sainty| first = Lane| title = These Groups Want Unnecessary Surgery On Intersex Infants To Be Made A Crime| work = [[Buzzfeed|BuzzFeed Australia]]| accessdate = 2017-03-21| date = March 13, 2017| url = https://www.buzzfeed.com/lanesainty/landmark-intersex-position-statement}}</ref>
=== Counseling services ===
Executive Director Mani Mitchell provides counselling for individuals and families.<ref name="herald2012" />
=== Youth ===
A youth project, Intersex Youth Aotearoa, was launched in September 2015, to provide information and support to youth with intersex conditions.<ref>{{cite web | title = ITANZ launch Intersex Youth Aotearoa | url = http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/CU1509/S00296/itanz-launch-intersex-youth-aotearoa.htm | date = September 18, 2015 | work = Scoop }}</ref><ref name="iad2016" />
=== Education and awareness ===
Mitchell, and other board members, have given presentations to a range of audiences, including the National College of Midwives biennial conference and the University of the Third Age.<ref name="mckenzie" /><ref>[http://www.familyplanning.org.nz/conference/programme Family Planning Conference 2013]</ref><ref>[http://www.hrc.co.nz/human-rights-environment/action-on-the-transgender-inquiry/intersex-people Intersex People], [[Human Rights Commission (New Zealand)|NZ Human Rights Commission]]</ref> The Trust have supported the filming of award-winning documentary [[Intersexion]] (2012).<ref>[http://www.gaystarnews.com/article/its-baby-truth-about-intersex150213 'It's a baby' - the truth about intersex], Gay Star News, 15 February 2013.</ref>
=== International organizing === Mitchell co-organized the third [[International Intersex Forum]] in Malta, 2013.<ref>[http://www.ilga-europe.org/home/news/latest/3rd_intersex_forum_2013 3rd International Intersex Forum in Malta] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131226222209/http://www.ilga-europe.org/home/news/latest/3rd_intersex_forum_2013 |date=2013-12-26 }}, ILGA-Europe, 22 July 2013</ref><ref>[http://www.gayexpress.co.nz/2013/12/the-3rd-international-intersex-forum-raises-important-issues/ The 3rd International Intersex Forum raises important issues], Gay Express, 3 December 2013.</ref>
== Affiliations == ITANZ a member of the [[International Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Trans and Intersex Association]].
== See also == * [[Intersex human rights]] * [[Intersex rights in New Zealand]]
== References ==
{{Reflist|30em}}
== External links ==
*{{official website|http://ianz.org.nz}}
{{intersex}}

revision.text:
'''Jimione (Jimmie) Isimeli Samisoni''' was the late former Dean of the [[Fiji School of Medicine]] (FSM).
==Biography== Samisoni attended [[Lelean Memorial School]] in 1949, passed his Senior Cambridge exams and matriculated to the then Central School of Medicine. The Central School of Medicine was later renamed the Fiji School of Medicine.
After receiving a fellowship from the [[World Health Organization]] (WHO), he went on to study at the [[Otago University]] where he graduated in 1959 with a Bachelor of Medicine. Later he continued post-graduate studies at the [[University of Queensland]] where he graduated with a Masters of Science degree.
Whilst studying for his [[Bachelor of Medicine and Bachelor of Surgery]] degree (MBBS), Jimmie Samisoni was also working towards his Doctorate (PhD)which he received in 1973.
From the mid to late 1970s, Dr Samisoni worked as a house surgeon in [[Queensland]]. He also worked as a senior lecturer at the [[Griffith University]] before returning to Fiji in 1980 where he joined the FSM.
During the year of the first [[1987 Fijian coups d'état|military coup in Fiji]] (1987), Dr Jimmie Samisoni left Fiji and joined the [[University of Hawaii]]'s [[John A. Burns School of Medicine|medical faculty]] as an assistant clinical professor.
Dr Samisoni was appointed the academic dean of the FSM when he came back to Fiji in 1990.
He retired from the FSM in 1998.
Dr Jimione Samisoni died in April 2007. He was married to Dr [[Mere Samisoni]] ([[Doctor of Business Administration|DBA]]) and they had four children. Dr[[Mere Samisoni]] is the Chairperson of the popular Hot Bread chain of stores in Fiji.
==References== * [http://www.rotuma.net/os/biographies/Jimione_Samisoni/Jimione_Samisoni.htm Dedicated to Science and Medicine - Dr Jimione Samisoni's life story by Dr Joji Malani, Fiji Times Online, 26 April 2007]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Samisoni, Jimione}} [[Category:2007 deaths]] [[Category:People educated at Lelean Memorial School]] [[Category:Fijian people of Rotuman descent]] [[Category:Year of birth missing]] [[Category:University of Otago alumni]] [[Category:University of Queensland alumni]] [[Category:University of Hawaii faculty]] [[Category:Fijian medical doctors]] [[Category:Fijian academics]] [[Category:Fijian expatriates in Australia]] [[Category:Fijian academic administrators]] [[Category:20th-century Fijian educators]]

Founded on December 7, 1946, the '''Lebanese Order of Physicians''' in Beirut is the largest medical organization and physician group in [[Lebanon]]. Its membership of 12,000 aims to pursue and promote optimal healthcare system and policies in Lebanon thus the region. Physicians are specialists who apply scientific knowledge and clinical expertise to the diagnosis, treatment, and compassionate care of adults across the spectrum from health to complex illness.
==Role== The Lebanese Order of Physicians’ mission is a medical, healthy, scientific, administrative, and a guiding mission that aims to:
# Unify the doctors’ word, defend their rights, maintain their legitimate moral and material interests, raise the level of their profession, and ensure the ethics and dignity of the medical care. # Discipline doctors to its laws and to the medical ethics. # Express an opinion and make suggestions for laws and regulations related to the profession of medicine and health agreements. # Express an opinion in sending medical missions and in attending international health conferences. # Coordinate with government institutions, especially with the Ministries of Public Health and Environment, to take the correct and useful decisions in the issues related to public health, and the formulation of national health policies. # Provide suggestions on the medical curriculum in colleges and institutes of medicine in Lebanon, and ensure the professional eligibility of physicians. # Contribute along with local and international institutions to defend human rights in health issues. # Coordinate with the Ministries of Public Health and Media on all matters related to public medical information and medical programs of any kind. # Express an opinion in the organization of the professions of assistance in the field of medicine. # Develop a manual on doctor fees. # Seek to solve the disputes that might occur among physicians or between them and their patients. # Help the doctors, or their families’, that are in need or with disabilities, and establish a retirement (pension) fund for aging and disability insurance. # Put a self-health insurance for the medical entity, and establish a synergistic fund for this purpose.
==Presidents== {| class="wikitable" heights="50" |- ! Position !! Photo !! Name !! Duration |- | 1 |||| '''Raif Abi Al-Lamaa''' || 1947–1948 |- | 2 |||| '''Mohamad Haidar''' || 1949–1950 |- | 3 |||| '''Joseph Al-Feghali''' || 1951–1952 |- | 4 |||| '''Najib Saad''' || 1953–1954 |- | 5 |||| '''Philip Chedid''' || 1955–1956 |- | 6 |||| '''Najib Saad''' || 1957–1958 |- | 7 |||| '''Antoine Hasri''' || 1959–1960 |- | 8 |||| '''Afif Mfarrej''' || 1961–1962 |- | 9 |||| '''Philip Chedid''' || 1963–1964 |- | 10 |||| '''Afif Mfarej''' || 1965–1966 |- | 11 |||| '''Antoine Hanin''' || 1967–1968 |- | 12 |||| '''Farid Haddad''' || 1969–1970 |- | 13 |||| '''Antoine Hanin''' || 1971–1972 |- | 14 |||| '''Joseph Azar''' || 1973–1974 |- | 15 |||| '''Fouad Al-Chemali''' || 1975–1987 |- | 16 |||| '''Michel Salhab''' || 1988–1989 |- | 17 |||| '''Mounir Rahme''' || 1990–1991 |- | 18 |||| '''Fouad Al-Boustani''' || 1992–1995 |- | 19 |||| '''Faek Youness''' || 1995–1998 |- | 20 |||| '''Ghattas Al-Khoury''' || 1998–2001 |- | 21 |||| '''Mahmoud Choucair''' || 2001–2004 |- | 22 |||| '''Mario Aoun''' || 2004–2007 |- | 23 |||| '''Georges Aftimos''' || 2007–2010 |- | 24 |||| '''Charaf Abou Charaf''' || 2010–2013 |- | 25 |||| '''Antoine Boustany''' || 2013–2016 |- | 26 |||| '''Raymond Sayegh''' || 2016 - |}

[[Image:Mercy Hospital in Miami Florida.jpg|thumb|Mercy Hospital in January 2008]]
'''Mercy Hospital''' is a 488-bed acute care U.S. [[hospital]] located in [[Coconut Grove]], [[Miami]], [[Florida]]. It is [[Miami-Dade]] County's only [[Catholic]] hospital.
Mercy Hospital was established in 1950. It was a member of the [[Catholic Health East]], and formerly sponsored by the [[Sisters of St. Joseph]] of [[St. Augustine, Florida]] until it was sold to HCA. The hospital has 2,300 full-time employees.
==Births== * Mexican Pop singer [[Paulina Rubio]] gave birth to her second son on March 5, 2016.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Tinoco|first1=Armando|title=Paulina Rubio Gives Birth To Baby Boy: Mexican Singer Welcomes 2nd Child In Miami|url=http://www.latintimes.com/paulina-rubio-gives-birth-baby-boy-mexican-singer-welcomes-2nd-child-miami-373545|accessdate=6 April 2016|work=[[Latin Times]]|date=7 March 2016}}</ref>
==Deaths== *[[Carlos Andrés Pérez]]<ref name=FC>{{cite web | url = http://www.eluniversal.com/2010/12/25/pol_ava_fallecio-en-el-ex-pr_25A4897053.shtml | title= Falleció el ex presidente Carlos Andrés Pérez | date=25 December 2010| author = El Universal | accessdate=25 December 2010|language=es}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
* The Miami Herald; "Two Catholic Hospitals to get One Boss" by John Dorschner; August 8, 2008; Page C
==External links== * [http://www.mercymiami.org Mercy Hospital]

{{coord|22.494795|N|28.579559|E|display=title}} [[File:Sheikh Zayed canal3.JPG|thumb|Sheikh Zayed canal of New Valley project, Libyan desert, Egypt]] [[File:Toshka syphon construction site.jpg|thumb|Construction site (2010) of the syphon that delivers water from the new valley project under the toshka spillway]] The '''New Valley Project''' or '''Toshka Project''' consists of building a system of canals to carry water from [[Lake Nasser]] to [[Irrigation|irrigate]] part of the sandy wastes of the [[Western Desert (Egypt)|Western Desert]] of [[Egypt]], which is part of the [[Sahara Desert]]. In 1997 the Egyptian government decided to develop a '''new valley''' (as opposed to the existing [[Nile Valley]]) where agricultural and industrial communities would develop. It has been an ambitious project which was meant to help Egypt cope with its rapidly growing population.
The canal inlet starts from a site 8 km to the north of Toshka Bay (Khor) on Lake Nasser. The canal is meant to continue westwards until it reaches the Darb el-Arbe'ien route, then northwards along the Darb el- Arbe'ien to the [[Baris, Egypt|Baris Oasis]], covering a distance of 310 km. But as of April 2012 the canal is still 60 km short of the Baris Oasis. The [[Mubarak Pumping Station]] in [[Toshka]] is the centerpiece of the project and was inaugurated in March 2005. It pumps water from Lake Nasser to be transported by way of a canal through the valley, with the idea of transforming 2340 km² (588,000 acres) of desert into agricultural land. The Toshka Project has now been revived by President [[Abdel Fattah el-Sisi]]. Half of the land will be given to college graduates, 1 acre each, funded by the Long Live Egypt Fund.
The essential problem is that the Western Desert's high saline levels and the presence of underground [[aquifer]]s in the area act as a major obstacle to any irrigation project. As the land is irrigated, the salt would mix with the aquifers and would reduce access to potable water. There is also the difficulty that the clay minerals found in the soil are posing technical problems to the big wheeled structures moving around autonomously to irrigate the land. Often their wheels get stuck in a little bowl created by wet clay that dried, and the irrigation machines come to a standstill. The only objective met up to April 2012 is the diversion of water from Lake Nasser into what little of the Sheikh Zayed Canal has been built.
The [[Toshka Lakes]] are a by-product of the rising level of [[Lake Nasser]] and lie in the same general region as much of the New Valley Project.
==See also== *[[New Valley Governorate]]
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20091104132655/http://www.mwri.gov.eg/En/project_toshka%20.html South Valley Development Project in Toshka], Egyptian Ministry of Water Resources and Irrigation * [http://www.thenational.ae/news/world/middle-east/egypts-new-nile-valley-grand-plan-gone-bad Egypt's new Nile Valley grand plan gone bad], ''The National'', 22 April 2012 * [http://www.egyptindependent.com/news/toshka-new-valleys-mega-failure/ On Toshka New Valley's mega-failure] * [http://www.water-technology.net/projects/mubarak/ Toshka Project - Mubarak Pumping Station / Sheikh Zayed Canal, Egypt] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080612195325/http://www.ipak.org/desert/photo/index.html Photographs Gallery]

'''Paraveterinary workers in Ireland''', such as veterinary nurses, assist [[veterinary physician]]s, or carry out animal health procedures autonomously. [[Paraveterinary workers]] in [[Ireland]] have been represented by the [[Irish Veterinary Nursing Association]] (IVNA) since 2002, and prior to this were represented by the British Veterinary Nursing Association (BVNA) from the 1960s.{{citation needed|date=January 2018}} The title "veterinary nurse" can only be used by those registered with the [[Veterinary Council of Ireland]].<ref name="mcCurin 2017"/> The post-nominal letters used in Ireland are RVN (Registered Veterinary Nurse).<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Self|first1=Georgina|title=RVN profile: Melanie O’Donoghue|journal=Veterinary Ireland Journal|date=May 2013|volume=3|issue=5|pages=236-238|url=http://www.veterinaryirelandjournal.com/images/nurse_may_2013.pdf|accessdate=2018-01-14}}</ref>
==Veterinary nursing== Veterinary nursing became a regulated profession in Ireland from January 2008, under the Veterinary Practice Act 2005.<ref name="mcCurin 2017">{{cite book|editor1-last=Bassert|editor1-first=Joanna M.|editor2-last=Samples|editor2-first=Oreta|editor3-last=Beal|editor3-first=Angela|title=McCurnin's Clinical Textbook for Veterinary Technicians|date=2017|isbn=9780323496407|page=1374|edition=9th}}</ref> When the act was implemented in January 2008, unqualified staff working in veterinary practices before 2004 had a period of six months to apply for provisional registration which conferred the same rights and responsibilities as full membership.<ref name="VP 2011"/> The provisional registration category ended on 31 December 2012.<ref name="VP 2011">{{cite web|title=Milestone celebrated|url=https://veterinary-practice.com/article/milestone-celebrated|website=Veterinary Practice|publisher=5m Enterprises Inc.|accessdate=2018-01-13|language=en|date=1 August 2011}}</ref>
Following the implementation of the Veterinary Practice Act in January 2008, no individual can legally perform veterinary nursing duties unless listed on the Register or is currently undertaking a course of formal education approved by the Veterinary Council.
Registered veterinary nurses must complete the required amount of [[continuing professional education]] each year to maintain their registration.<ref name="Harvey 2014">{{cite journal|last1=Harvey|first1=Laura|last2=Ladyman|first2=Rebecca|last3=Farnworth|first3=Mark|title=International differences in the journey toward compulsory veterinary nurse registration|journal=The Veterinary Nurse|date=2 November 2014|volume=5|issue=9|pages=538–542|doi=10.12968/vetn.2014.5.9.538}}</ref>
A 2016 survey found that the majority of registered veterinary nurses were women, and that the average age was 32.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=McDonnell|first1=Lorraine|title=Veterinary Nursing Survey|journal=Veterinary Ireland Journal|date=August 2016|volume=6|issue=8|pages=423-424|url=http://www.veterinaryirelandjournal.com/images/nurse_aug_2016.pdf}}</ref>
===Qualifications=== There are five programmes of study which qualify one to become a veterinary nurse in Ireland, each sanctioned by the [[Veterinary Council of Ireland]]: the 2-year diploma course at [[St. John's Central College]] in Cork, the 3-year ordinary Bachelor of Science degrees in [[Athlone, Dundalk and Letterkenny Institutes of Technology]] and the 4-year higher (honours level) Bachelor of Science degree at [[University College Dublin]].{{citation needed|date=January 2018}} Qualifications gained outside of Ireland may be recognised by the Veterinary Council as being equivalent to Ireland's veterinary nursing qualifications.<ref name="Harvey 2014" />
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.ivna.ie/ Irish Veterinary Nurses Association]

{{Use British English|date=April 2016}} {{Infobox Christian leader | type = priest | honorific-prefix = [[The Very Reverend]]
[[Servant of God]] | name = Pedro Arrupe Gondra | honorific-suffix = [[Society of Jesus|SJ]] | title = 28th [[Superior General of the Society of Jesus]] | image = | image_size = 220px | alt = | caption = | elected = | term_start = 22 May 1965 | quashed = | term_end = 3 September 1983
paralyzing stroke | predecessor = [[Jean-Baptiste Janssens]] | successor = [[Peter Hans Kolvenbach]] | opposed = | other_post = | ordination = 30 July 1936 | ordained_by = | consecration = | consecrated_by = | cardinal = | rank = | created_cardinal_by = | birth_name = Pedro de Arrupe y Gondra | birth_date = {{Birth date|1907|11|14|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Bilbao]], [[Basque Country (autonomous community)|Basque Country]], [[Restoration (Spain)|Spain]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1991|02|05|1907|11|14|df=y}} | death_place = [[Rome]], [[Italy]] | buried = [[Church of the Gesù]], [[Rome]] | nationality = [[Spaniards|Spanish]] | religion = [[Catholic Church|Roman Catholic]] | residence = | parents = | spouse = | children = | occupation = | profession = | alma_mater = [[Complutense University of Madrid]] | signature = | coat_of_arms = | motto = | resting_place_coordinates = | education = | signature_alt = | coat_of_arms_alt = | feast_day = | venerated = [[Roman Catholic Church]] | saint_title = [[Servant of God]] | beatified_date = | beatified_place = | beatified_by = | canonized_date = | canonized_place = | canonized_by = | attributes = | patronage = | shrine = | suppressed_date = | other = | module = }} {{Spanish name|Arrupe|Gondra}} '''Pedro Arrupe''' {{post-nominals|post-noms=[[Society of Jesus|SJ]]}} (14 November 1907 – 5 February 1991) was a Spanish [[Basque people|Basque]] [[Jesuit]] priest who served as the twenty-eighth [[Superior General of the Society of Jesus]] (1965–83). Stationed as novice master outside [[Hiroshima]] in 1945, he used his medical background as a first responder to the [[Atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki|atomic bombing of Hiroshima.]] He led the Jesuits in the implementation of the [[Second Vatican Council]], especially with regard to a faith that does justice and [[preferential option for the poor#Origin and usage|preferential option for the poor]].{{Cite web|url=https://president.georgetown.edu/pedro-arrupe-sj|title=Pedro Arrupe, S.J.|website=president.georgetown.edu|language=en|access-date=2017-06-02}} ==Education and training== Pedro Arrupe attended school at the Santiago Apostol High School in [[Bilbao]]. Later he moved to [[Madrid]] to attend the Medical School of the [[Complutense University of Madrid|Universidad Complutense]]. There he met [[Severo Ochoa]], who later won the [[Nobel Prize in Medicine]]. One of his teachers was [[Juan Negrín]], a pioneer in physiology, who would become [[Prime Minister]] of the [[Second Spanish Republic|Spanish Republic]] during the [[Spanish Civil War|Civil War]] (1936–1939). Arrupe received the top prize in the first year anatomy course. After some years of medical training, Pedro Arrupe joined the Jesuits in 1927 but was unable to pursue his studies for the [[Priesthood (Catholic Church)|priesthood]] in Spain, since the Order had been expelled by the [[Spanish Republican]] government (1931-1939). Accordingly, the young Arrupe did his studies in the [[Netherlands]] and [[Belgium]] and at [[Saint Louis University|St. Louis University]] School of Divinity in [[St. Marys, Kansas]], where he was ordained in 1936.{{Cite news|url=https://www.britannica.com/biography/Pedro-Arrupe|title=Pedro Arrupe {{!}} Biography, Facts, & Hiroshima|work=Encyclopedia Britannica|access-date=2018-05-11|language=en}}{{Cite web|url=https://kenrick.edu/about/administration-and-faculty-2/|title=Administration/Faculty|website=kenrick.edu|language=en-US|access-date=2018-05-11}} Arrupe then completed a doctorate in [[Medical Ethics]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.ignatianspirituality.com/ignatian-voices/20th-century-ignatian-voices/pedro-arrupe-sj/|title=Pedro Arrupe, SJ (1907—1991) - IgnatianSpirituality.com|work=Ignatian Spirituality|access-date=2017-06-02|language=en-US}} ==Japan - Hiroshima== After his doctorate, Arrupe was sent to work as a missionary in [[Japan]]. His early years as missionary were very frustrating for him. No matter what he did, what he organised, people did not attend, and few if any converted to Christianity. When the [[attack on Pearl Harbor]] occurred in [[Hawaii]] on 7 December 1941, it was 8 December in Japan. Arrupe was celebrating the [[Eucharist]] for the Solemnity of the [[Immaculate Conception]] when he was arrested and imprisoned for a time, being suspected of espionage. On [[Christmas]] Eve, Arrupe heard people gathering outside his cell door and presumed that the time for him to be executed had arrived. However, to his utter surprise, he discovered that some fellow [[Catholics]], ignoring all danger, had come to sing him [[Christmas carols]]. Upon this realization, Arrupe recalled that he burst into tears. His attitude of profound prayer and his lack of offensive behaviour gained him the respect of his jailers and judges, and he was set free within a month. Arrupe was appointed Jesuit superior and [[novice]] master in Japan in 1942, and was living in suburban [[Hiroshima]] when the [[Atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki|atomic bomb fell in August 1945]]. He was one of 8 Jesuits who were within the blast zone of the bomb, and all 8 survived the destruction. Arrupe described that event as "a permanent experience outside of history, engraved on my memory."[http://www.arrupe.org/en/father_pedro.html Arrupe Formation Centre website: Arrupe] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110725013909/http://www.arrupe.org/en/father_pedro.html |date=2011-07-25 }} Father Arrupe used his medical skills to help those who were wounded or dying. The Jesuit [[novitiate]] was converted into a makeshift hospital where between 150 and 200 people received care. Arrupe recalled, "The chapel, half destroyed, was overflowing with the wounded, who were lying on the floor very near to one another, suffering terribly, twisted with pain."{{Cite web|url=http://www.eurekastreet.com.au/article.aspx?aeid=3219|title=Hiroshima insider's imprint on Jesuit sensibility - Eureka Street|website=www.eurekastreet.com.au|language=en|access-date=2017-06-01}} In 1958, Arrupe was appointed the first Jesuit [[Provincial superior|provincial]] for Japan, a position he held until being elected Father General in 1965. Prior to being elected Father General, Arrupe made a visit to [[Latin America]] and, on one occasion, was celebrating the [[Eucharist]] in a suburban slum. He was deeply moved at the devotion and respect the people had for Christ in the midst of their abject poverty. After the service, a man invited Arrupe to his hovel, where he told him that he was so grateful for his visit and that he wanted to share the only gift he had, that of watching the setting sun together. Arrupe reflected, "He gave me his hand. As I was leaving, I thought: 'I have met very few hearts that are so kind.'"{{Cite news|url=http://ignatianspirituality.com/ignatian-voices/20th-century-ignatian-voices/pedro-arrupe-sj/|title=Pedro Arrupe, SJ (1907—1991) - IgnatianSpirituality.com|work=Ignatian Spirituality|access-date=2017-06-01|language=en-US}} == Superior General == At the thirty-first [[General Congregation]] of the Society of Jesus in 1965, Arrupe was elected twenty-eighth [[Superior General of the Society of Jesus|Superior General]] of the Jesuits, and served in that post until 1983. He was only the second [[Basque people|Basque]] to be Father General, the first being the founder [[Saint Ignatius of Loyola]] himself. Jesuit [[Vincent O'Keefe]], a friend and advisor to Arrupe, said Arrupe was "a second Ignatius of Loyola, a refounder of the Society in the light of Vatican II."{{cite news | work=New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/06/obituaries/pedro-arrupe-jesuit-chief-for-18-years-dies-at-83.html |date=6 February 1991 | quote =Father Arrupe had embarked upon his role as Superior General with enthusiasm for the revisionist themes of Vatican II.... He cautioned the world Synod of Bishops in 1971 against 'authoritarian or paternalistic attitudes'.... He insisted that the Jesuit order, long identified with work among social and political elites, increase its activities among the poor.... He also introduced new forms of decentralization into the Jesuit decision-making process.}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.americamagazine.org/issue/100/don-pedro-history-2|title="Reinvention" of Society of Jesus, from obit in America|last=|first=|date=1991-02-16|work=America Magazine|access-date=2017-03-14|language=en}} At his election [[Moscow]] radio spoke of an unusual man who would bring the Society of Jesus to its powers of the past.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AKQUaKfl5yAC&pg=PA218&|title=Pedro Arrupe, SJ| date=2000| publisher=Gracewing|isbn=9780852444467|location=England|authorlink=George Bishop|accessdate=13 July 2018}}{{rp|218}} After the changes following [[Vatican II]] (1962–1965), there was tension within the Society as to how the life of a Jesuit was to be lived. While some [[religious order|religious group]]s in the [[Catholic Church|Catholic church]] have limits on the works they take on, the Society of Jesus encourages its members to follow their interest and talents and the needs of the times into a whole range of ministries – as theologians, missionaries, retreat directors, teachers, artists, writers, musicians, counselors, scientists, and pastors – to bring [[AMDG|glory to God]] in all areas of human endeavor.{{Cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,945242-2,00.html|title=The Jesuits' Search For a New Identity|date=1973-04-23|work=Time|access-date=2017-06-01|language=en-US|issn=0040-781X}} This is in line with the crowning contemplation of Ignatius' [[Spiritual Exercises of Ignatius of Loyola|Spiritual Exercises]] through which Jesuits learn to find God in all things (#236). As Arrupe's biographer said of him, he "saw the hand of God in everything."{{rp|226}} Arrupe warned of repeating the answers of yesterday for tomorrow's problems, saying: "If we speak a language no longer appropriate to the hearts of people, we speak only to ourselves because no one will listen to us or try to understand what we say."{{rp|228}} Arrupe was "hailed as a prophet of our time,"{{rp|231}} not unlike Jesuit [[Pope Francis]] who was in theological studies, learning, when Arrupe became Superior General and began speaking his "prophetic" words. The Union of Superior Generals of religious, seeing Arrupe as the right man for our time, elected him five times as their president.{{rp|231}} === Faith and justice === At the thirty-second General Congregation which convened in 1975, Arrupe's dream of working for the poor was crystallised in the document "Our Mission Today: the Service of Faith and the Promotion of Justice." It stated: "Our faith in Jesus Christ and our mission to proclaim the Gospel demand of us a commitment to promote justice and enter into solidarity with the voiceless and the powerless."[http://www.jcu.edu/arrupe/pedro.htm John Carroll University: About Pedro Arrupe] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100528155040/http://www.jcu.edu/arrupe/pedro.htm |date=May 28, 2010 }} Thus, the decree basically defined all the work of the Jesuits as having an essential focus on the promotion of [[social justice]] as well as the [[Catholic]] faith. Arrupe was keenly aware that in the political climate of the 1970s, the Jesuits’ commitment to working for social justice would bring great hardship and suffering, particularly in those [[Latin America]]n countries ruled by military [[Military dictatorship|junta]]s.[http://www.bc.edu/offices/ministry/arrupe/pedro.html Boston College Website: Arrupe] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100326070907/http://www.bc.edu/offices/ministry/arrupe/pedro.html |date=March 26, 2010 }} In a speech to European educators Arrupe made it clear where he stood on matters of faith and justice, saying: "I take very seriously the words of Gandhi, 'I love Christ but I despise Christians because they do not live as Christ lived.' Without a doubt Christian love of neighbor entails a duty to care for the wounds of those that have fallen victim to robbers and are left bleeding by the wayside."{{rp|270}} In the late 1960s and into the 1980s some [[theologians]] in Latin America became increasingly involved in the political sphere, adopting [[Marxist]] rhetoric. Many Jesuits were at the forefront of the movement which was called [[liberation theology]] and concentrated on seeing [[Christ]] as the liberator not only from sin but from all forms of oppression. In its extreme manifestations, liberation theology seemed to subordinate the message of the [[Gospel]] to political revolution, with a wholesale acceptance of Marxism. But Arrupe's strong support for relieving the burden of the poor in Latin America enables one to see his "cautionary statements about liberation theology,... as efforts to impose self-discipline to fend off more severe sanctions from outside the order."{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/06/obituaries/pedro-arrupe-jesuit-chief-for-18-years-dies-at-83.html|title=New York Times|last=|first=|date=6 February 1991|work=|access-date=14 March 2017}} === A cause worth dying for === On 20 June 1977 the White Warriors Union death squad threatened to kill all 47 Jesuits serving in [[El Salvador]] unless they abandoned their work with the poor and left the country within a month.{{Cite web|url=http://archives.chicagotribune.com/1977/07/20/page/B4/article/el-salvador-priests-in-peril|title=El Salvador priests in peril (July 20, 1977)|access-date=2017-06-02}} After consulting with the Jesuit community in El Salvador, Arrupe replied "They may end up as martyrs, but my priests are not going to leave because they are with the people."{{Citation needed|date=June 2013}} A few months earlier, Jesuit Father [[Rutilio Grande]], a proponent of liberation theology, was assassinated in El Salvador. On 16 November 1989, six Jesuits ([[Ignacio Ellacuría]], Armando Lopez, Joaquin Lopez y Lopez, [[Ignacio Martín-Baró]], [[Segundo Montes]] and Juan Ramon Moreno, along with their housekeeper (Julia Elba Ramos) and her daughter (Celina), would be murdered at the Jesuit [[University of Central America]]. Others also suffered [[martyr]]dom: the chief bishop in El Salvador Archbishop [[Óscar Romero]] (though conservative in respect to religion) was gunned down whilst celebrating the Eucharist on 24 March 1980. Lay missionary [[Jean Donovan]], [[Ursulines|Ursuline]] sister [[Dorothy Kazel]] and [[Maryknoll Sisters of St. Dominic|Maryknoll]] sisters [[Maura Clarke]] and [[Ita Ford]] were beaten, raped and murdered by non-uniformed members of the [[National Guard (El Salvador)|Salvadoran National Guard]] on 2 December 1980.{{Cite book|title=Paying the Price: Ignacio Ellacuría and the Murdered Jesuits of El Salvador|last=Whitfield|first=Teresa|publisher=Temple U|year=1994|isbn=1566392535|location=|pages=}} They joined some 75,000 Salvadorans who were killed during this troubled period.{{rp|97}} All the while, Arrupe continued to support and pray for those people who were willing to lay down their lives to help the poor initiate change. === Jesuit Refugee Service === Touched by the plight of the "[[Vietnam]]ese boat people" in 1979, Pedro Arrupe sent cable messages to some 20 Jesuit major superiors throughout the world sharing his distress at the suffering of these people. He asked them what they could do to help bring relief to refugees and displaced persons in their own regions. He received a positive response, with numerous offers of personnel, medicine, and funding. The next year in 1980 Arrupe founded the [[Jesuit Refugee Service]] to coordinate the Society's refugee work. In a speech launching the service he said "Saint Ignatius called us to go anywhere where we are most needed for the [[Ad maiorem Dei gloriam|greater glory of God]]. The spiritual as well as the material need of more than 16 million refugees throughout the world today could scarcely be greater. God is calling us through these helpless people." In 2017 JRS listed 47 countries where its 10 regional offices were currently serving nearly 950,000 individuals.{{Cite web|url=http://en.jrs.net/Regions|title=Jesuit Refugee Service {{!}} Where we work|last=Service|first=Jesuit Refugee|website=en.jrs.net|language=en|access-date=2017-03-15}} Over the years JRS had served an estimated 40 million refugees. ==Later life== On 7 August 1981, after a long and tiring trip throughout the [[Far East]], Arrupe suffered a stroke just after his aeroplane landed at [[Rome]]'s [[Fiumicino Airport]]. He was paralysed on his right side and was able to speak only a few words. This ability gradually deteriorated until he was completely mute. From that time on he lived in the infirmary at the Jesuit headquarters in Rome. He was the first Jesuit Superior-General to resign instead of remaining in office until his death. Pope [[John Paul II]] appointed [[Paolo Dezza]] as his personal delegate and interim Father General of the Society, passing over Arrupe's own choice (his vicar general). There was a wave of resentment in the Society as this was seen as unwarranted papal interference in Jesuit affairs. For his part, Arrupe never expressed any disagreement or resentment. In 1983, Dezza called the thirty-third General Congregation to deal with the resignation of Arrupe and the election of a successor. Arrupe's resignation was accepted on 3 September 1983 during the Congregation and it proceeded to elect [[Peter Hans Kolvenbach]] as Father General. During the opening Session of the Congregation, Arrupe was wheeled into the hall, and a prayer which he had written was read aloud: {{quote|More than ever I find myself in the hands of God. This is what I have wanted all my life from my youth. But now there is a difference; the initiative is entirely with God. It is indeed a profound spiritual experience to know and feel myself so totally in God's hands.}} During his ten years in the infirmary, praying for and with the Society, Arrupe received many and frequent well-wishers, including Pope John Paul II. Arrupe had earlier expressed what some regard as the key to his life: "Nowadays the world does not need words but lives that cannot be explained except through faith and love for Christ's poor." === Death and burial === Arrupe died on 5 February 1991. His funeral was held in the [[Church of the Gesu]], Rome, and was attended by crowds that filled the [[piazza]] outside the church. Also in attendance were 10 [[Cardinal (Catholic Church)|cardinals]], 20 bishops, [[Giulio Andreotti]] the [[Prime Minister of Italy]], as well as other religious and civil dignitaries. His body, first interred in the Jesuit mausoleum at [[Campo Verano]], was brought back into the [[Church of the Gesù]] where it lies in a side chapel.{{Cite web|url=http://www.americamagazine.org/issue/100/creative-fidelity-pedro-arrupe|title=Memorial Mass|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=2 June 2017}} == Veneration == On 11 July 2018, the Father General of the Society of Jesus, [[Arturo Sosa]], announced the beginning of the process for his beatification.{{Cite news|url=https://www.vaticannews.va/en/church/news/2018-07/arrupe-jesuit-beatification-rome-diocese.html|title=Rome Diocese opens beatification process of Jesuit superior general Fr. Arrupe - Vatican News|date=2018-07-26|access-date=2018-11-14|language=en}} By 14 November 2018 a website was established with the life, testimonials, and archive on Pedro Arrupe.{{Cite web|url=https://arrupe.jesuitgeneral.org/en|title=Pedro Arrupe - Arrupe|last=User|first=Super|website=arrupe.jesuitgeneral.org|language=en-gb|access-date=2018-11-14}} ==Memorials== [[File:Pedro Arrupe, S.J., memorial - University of San Francisco - San Francisco, CA - DSC02663.JPG|thumb|upright|Pedro Arrupe memorial at [[University of San Francisco]], California, United States]] Numerous buildings, schools and Jesuit communities have been named after Pedro Arrupe. They include: *The Colégio Pedro Arrupe a private school in Portugal dedicated to Arrupe opened in 2009. *The Sports hall in [[Wimbledon College]], London *The Pedro Arrupe Center for Business Ethics at [[Saint Joseph's University]] in [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]] *A residence hall at the [[University of San Francisco]] *A building in [[Fairfield College Preparatory School]], [[Connecticut]] *The Fr. Pedro Arrupe Campus Ministry Center at [[Fairfield University]] *The main auditorium at the [[ITESO]], a Jesuit university in [[Guadalajara]], Mexico *[[Arrupe Jesuit High School]], [[Denver]], [[Colorado]] *The middle school of [[Boston College High School]], was named the "Arrupe Division" in 2007 *Arrupe Jesuit University - AJU [Harare, Zimbabwe] *A school in [[Philippines]], named Pedro Arrupe Academy. *The neighbourhood partnership program named the Arrupe House at [[Saint Ignatius High School (Cleveland)|Saint Ignatius High School]] in Cleveland, Ohio. *The "Arrupe Scholars" scholarship program at [[John Carroll University]], Cleveland, Ohio{{Cite web|url=http://sites.jcu.edu/arrupe/|title=Arrupe Scholars Program|website=sites.jcu.edu|language=en-US|access-date=2017-03-14}} * A building in Pontifical Xavierian University in Bogota, Colombia. * A class taken by Seniors at [[Creighton Preparatory School]] in [[Omaha, Nebraska]], called the "Arrupe Experience Service Class" where the students make service trips every other day to local schools. *The Fr. Pedro Arrupe S.J. Office of Faith and Justice serves the students of [[Brophy College Preparatory]] by organizing service trips, immersion experiences, retreats, the annual Summit on Human Dignity, and much more. * Arrupe College of [[Loyola University Chicago]]'s Water Tower Campus is a 2-year college designed to serve underrepresented and underserved students. On their Lake Shore Campus, one of the Jesuit Community Houses is named Arrupe House, but has no direct tie to Arrupe College. *[[Jesuit High School (Beaverton, Oregon)|Jesuit High School]] in [[Portland, Oregon]] has its History, English and Library building named after Pedro Arrupe. *A residence hall at [[Loyola University Maryland]], Baltimore, Maryland. *A building in the [[Saint Louis University]], Madrid Campus, called Padre Arrupe Hall. *The Arrupe Office of Social Formation in [[Ateneo de Davao University]], Davao City, Philippines. *A building on the campus of [[Rockhurst University]] in [[Kansas City, Missouri|Kansas City]], [[Missouri]], called Pedro Arrupe, SJ, Hall which opened in 2015. *A residence hall at [[Georgetown University]] in [[Washington, D.C.]], called Pedro Arrupe, S.J. Hall, which was opened in August 2016.{{Cite web|url=https://studentliving.georgetown.edu/residences/PedroArrupe|title=Pedro Arrupe, S.J. Hall|website=studentliving.georgetown.edu|access-date=2016-07-27}} *Arrupe International Residence at Ateneo de Manila University, Philippines. * {{ill|Pedro Arrupe Footbridge|es|Pasarela Pedro Arrupe}} (Bilbao, Spain) links the Guggenheim museum to the [[University of Deusto]].{{cite web |url=http://www.bilbaoturismo.net/BilbaoTurismo/en/nuevos-puentes/-pedro-arrupe-footbridge|title= Pedro Arrupe Footbridge|website=bilbaoturismo.net|access-date=2018-09-26}} *Pedro Arrupe Human Rights Institute, an academic institution attached to the University of Deusto in Bilbao.{{cite web |url=https://socialesyhumanas.deusto.es/cs/Satellite/socialesyhumanas/en/institute-of-human-rights?cambioidioma=si|title= The Pedro Arrupe Human Rights Institute|website=socialesyhumanas.deusto.es|access-date=2018-09-26}} *Arrupe Etxea, a civilian foundation initially covering all the social and pastoral activity of the jesuits in Bilbao and, since 2014, also [[San Sebastian]], [[Vitoria-Gasteiz]] and [[Pamplona]].{{cite web |url=https://arrupeetxea.org/|title= Arrupe Etxea|website=arrupeetxea.org|access-date=2018-09-26}} ==Gallery== File:Loyolaschoolsjf2057 05.JPG|Arrupe International Residence at [[Ateneo de Manila University]] File:Loyolaschoolsjf2057 08.JPG|Entrance to Residence at Ateneo File:Arrupe Hall cut.png| Pedro Arrupe, S.J., Hall, [[Rockhurst University]], [[Kansas City]], MO, USA File:Auditorio Pedro Arrupe.jpg|Arrupe Auditorio, Instituto Tecnológico, Guadalajara, Mexico ==References== {{Reflist}} | after=[[Peter Hans Kolvenbach]] | years=1965–1983}} {{s-end}} {{Subject bar|portal1=Biography|portal2=Catholicism|portal3=Spain|commons=yes|commons-search=Category:Pedro {{COI|date=December 2017}}
{{Infobox Union |name= PEF |full_name= Public Employees Federation |image= [[File:NYS Public Employees Federation logo.jpg|frameless]] |founded= {{Start date|1978}} |country= [[United States]] |office= 1168-70 Troy Schenectady Rd, Latham, NY 12110 , New York |people= Wayne Spence, President, Kevin Hintz Secretary-Treasurer, Adreina Adams Vice-President, Peter Banks Vice-President Nikki Brate Vice-President |website= {{URL|www.pef.org}} |affiliation= [[American Federation of Teachers|AFT]] ([[AFL-CIO]]), [[Service Employees International Union|SEIU]] ([[Change to Win Federation|CtW]]) |members= 50,596 (2014)<ref name="OLMS_LM-2_2014-06-29">{{Cite OLMS|filenum=519-220|rptId=557862|rptForm=LM2Form|date=June 29, 2014}}</ref><ref>This membership number is down from the 58,000 members reported by the media in February 2008. See: "State, PEF Announce Tentative 4-Year Contract," ''Albany Times-Union,'' February 6, 2008.</ref> |native_name= |current= |head= |dissolved_date= |dissolved_state= |merged_into= |footnotes= }}<!-- Include all unused fields for future use. See {{Infobox Union}} for usage. --> The '''Public Employees Federation''' ('''PEF''') is an [[United States|American]] [[trade union|union]] representing 54,000<ref name="OLMS_LM-2_2014-06-29"/> professional, scientific, and technical public employees in the state of [[New York (state)|New York]]. The union is one of the largest local [[white-collar worker|white-collar]] unions in the United States and is New York's second-largest state-employee union.<ref>Northrup, [http://blog.timesunion.com/stateworker/layoff-plans-in-motion-pef-wonders-what-happened-to-retirement-incentive/705/ "Layoff Plans in Motion, PEF Wonders What Happened to Retirement Incentive,"] ''Albany Times-Union,'' July 22, 2010.</ref> PEF also represents employees who work in private-sector jobs and local government agencies. The union publishes ''The Communicator'', online newsletter with a 2007 distribution of 70,000, on a monthly basis.<ref>Zipser, "Postal Rate Hike Hits Labor Press," ''The Guild Reporter,'' September 14, 2007.</ref>
==Composition== {{thumb|width=250|content= {{center|'''Membership (US records)'''<ref name="OLMS">{{Cite OLMS|filenum=519-220}}</ref>}}{{Line chart | padding_top = 5 | padding_bottom = 15 | interval_primary_scale = 5000 | interval_secondary_scale = 2500 | label_x1 = 2000 | label_x2 = | label_x3 = | label_x4 = | label_x5 = | label_x6 = 2005 | label_x7 = | label_x8 = | label_x9 = | S04V01 = 23100 | S01V02 = 9103 | S02V02 = 12677 | S03V02 = 25839 | S04V02 = 25625 | S01V03 = 12007 | S02V03 = 12199 | S03V03 = 27621 | S04V03 = 24713 | S01V04 = 13710 | S02V04 = 12018 | S03V04 = 27802 | S04V04 = 28028 | S01V05 = 13170 | S02V05 = 11819 | S03V05 = 28747 | S04V05 = 27894 | S01V06 = 12295 | S02V06 = 10950 | S03V06 = 29526 | S04V06 = 29964 | S01V07 = 11717 | S02V07 = 10649 | S03V07 =
